The use of mercenaries during the Crusades had a significant impact on the development of modern military practices, as it introduced the concept of professional soldiers who were hired to fight in wars. Today, many armies around the world use mercenaries, also known as private military contractors or security contractors, in a variety of roles.

One of the main advantages of using mercenaries is that they are often highly trained and highly experienced soldiers who are able to operate effectively in a variety of environments. They are also more flexible and adaptable than regular soldiers, as they can be hired to perform specific tasks or operate in specific regions. This has made them a valuable asset in many modern conflicts, especially those fought in regions where traditional military forces may not be able to operate effectively.

However, the use of mercenaries has also been controversial, as it can lead to a lack of accountability and oversight. Some argue that mercenaries may be more likely to engage in unethical or illegal conduct, as they are not subject to the same rules or regulations as regular soldiers. Moreover, the use of mercenaries can lead to a blurring of the line between military and civilian roles, as they are often hired to perform tasks that would traditionally be the responsibility of regular military forces, such as providing security or performing logistics support.

Overall, the use of mercenaries during the Crusades had a lasting impact on the development of modern military practices, and the legacy of this practice can still be seen in the way that many armies operate today.
